lines.text: The Pope considered me despicable, yet he crossed the Alps to anoint me. The King of Austria called me a Corsican gutter rat, and gave me his daughter as a bride. Anyone can make use of a friend. The trick is to use one's enemies.

Apart from my duties as your physician, I'm required to report daily that I've seen you as a precaution against escape. I agreed to obey that order on the condition that I could inform you of it. I'm not a spy.
I have nothing against spies.
I'd like a bible.
It never occurred to me that you were religious.
I only read the love poetry. And the battle scenes. You can learn a lot from those Old Testament boys.
Power is my art. I love it. The way a musician loves his instrument.
You think there's always a choice between good and evil? Sometimes there's only a choice between horrors.
Papa is sending me to school in London. God, how I longed for it! Begged him! He wouldn't hear of it.
How did you manage?
I told him I was in love with you. He can't wait to pack me off.
When I go into battle, I never bother to take food for all my troops. It stands to reason some of them will be killed. Why bother hauling provisions for corpses?
[first lines]
Allow me to introduce myself.
That's quite unnecessary. I know who you are.
You are free to move anywhere on the island, provided you are accompanied by an English officer.
I am not your prisoner.
You held a great deal of power for a very long time. I expect it's not easy to accept someone else in command. Nevertheless, that is the fact of the matter.
Why, when a respectable man does something despicable, does he always insist it's his duty?

Could I say although this is the first time I've had the honor of meeting you in person, I've long regarded you with the utmost admiration; well aware that you make a point of keeping out of the public eye, and that many of your countrymen are unaware of the historic services that you have rendered to...

[interrupting]
Do you always talk so much, or is it a disease one catches out here?
those who will use you, and those you can use.
Ah, Thomas.
Yes sir?
Saw your father before I left. Asked me to inquire how you were getting on.

[who thinks his father is a political sell-out]
Tell him I'm working on a plot to burn Parliament.

[laughing]
I'll tell him! Never liked your father. Puritanical bastard! Stupid as a flatiron!

[laughing]
Set fire to Parliament! That's it! Incinerate the bastards!
Either accept our terms, or you hang. It's what's known in the law books as blackmail, and in the history books as statesmanship.
[last lines]
It appears the gentleman will be staying. Carry on as before.
